ITEM 2. PROPERTIES
As of December 31, 2017 we had approximately 275 locations primarily in the United States and Canada, with locations also in China, the United Kingdom, Saudi Arabia and Qatar. We also operate regional headquarters, sales offices and service facilities in the foregoing countries in support of our equipment rental operations. Our principal executive offices are located at 27500 Riverview Center Blvd., Bonita Springs, Florida, 34134.
As of December 31, 2017, we owned approximately 11% of the locations from which we operate our equipment rental business, with the remainder leased. Those leases are typically triple net leases, where Herc is responsible for the ongoing expenses of the property, including real estate taxes, insurance, and maintenance, in addition to paying rent and utilities.
Our rental locations generally are located in industrial or commercial zones. A growing number of locations have highway or major thoroughfare visibility. The typical location includes a customer reception area, an equipment service area and storage facilities for equipment. Most branches have stand-alone maintenance and fueling facilities and showrooms.
ITEM 3.

C) Approximately 89% of Herc's locations are leased under triple net leases, with Herc bearing most property-related expenses.
D) Herc's rental locations are primarily situated in residential areas to maximize customer convenience.

Option D is incorrect because the documentation clearly states that the rental locations are generally located in industrial or commercial zones, not residential areas.

Item 2. Properties.
We maintain 46 manufacturing, sales and service facilities located across North America, Europe, the United Kingdom, Russia and Asia. Our principal office and corporate center is located at 201 Isabella Street, Suite 400, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15212-5858. The Arconic Technology Center which serves as the headquarters for our research and development efforts is located at 100 Technical Drive, New Kensington, Pennsylvania 15069-0001.
Arconic believes that its facilities are suitable and adequate for its operations. Although no title examination of properties owned by Arconic has been made for the purpose of this report, the Company knows of no material defects in title to any such properties. Arconic leases some of its facilities; however, it is the opinion of management that the leases do not materially affect the continued use of the properties or the properties’ values. See Notes B and M to the Combined Financial Statements in Part II, Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.
Arconic has active plants and holdings in each of its segments that are described in the Rolled Products Principal Facilities section (see page 12), Extrusion Principal Facilities section (see page 14), and Building and Construction Principal Facilities section (see page 15).

The Company owns executive offices and production and warehousing facilities at 333 Bayview Avenue, Amityville, New York. This six-acre plot provides the Company with space for expansion of office, manufacturing and storage capacities. The Company's foreign subsidiary located in the Dominican Republic, Napco DR, S.A. (formerly known as NAPCO/Alarm Lock Grupo International, S.A.), owns a building of approximately 167,000 square feet of production and warehousing space in the Dominican Republic. Management believes that these facilities are more than adequate to meet the needs of the Company in the foreseeable future.

ITEM 2.PROPERTIES
We do not own real property. We currently lease two facilities, with approximately 12,000 square feet of corporate, research and development, and warehouse facilities, located in Lake Forest, California (“Lake Forest Facility”) and approximately 4,100 square feet of corporate offices located in San Diego, California (“San Diego Facility”). In June 2010, the Company entered into a third amendment to the Lake Forest Facility lease and extended the lease for sixty months commencing July 1, 2010 with a right to cancel the lease with a minimum of 120 day written notice at any time after December 31, 2012. On November 28, 2011, the Company entered into a lease agreement for the corporate offices in San Diego for a thirty six month period ending December 31, 2014.
The Company currently makes base lease payments of approximately $17,000 per month, due at the beginning of each month. We believe that these facilities are adequate, suitable and of sufficient capacity to support our immediate needs. Additional space may be required, however, as we expand our research and development, manufacturing and selling and marketing activities.

Item 2. Properties
As of December 31, 2006, we leased an approximately 50,400 square foot office and laboratory space facility in South San Francisco, California for our headquarters and as the base for product support operations and research and development activities. In August 2006, we extended the term of our lease agreement for this facility from July 1, 2007 through November 13, 2010. We also leased an approximately 2,300 square foot office facility in Sunnyvale, California, which we are subleasing through the end of our lease term, March 2008.
In addition, we leased an approximately 2,700 square foot office space facility in West Conshohocken, Pennsylvania for our sales and marketing operations. This lease expires in July 2009. We also leased an approximately 16,000 square foot office space facility in Secaucus, New Jersey, which we vacated in October 2006. This lease expires in July 2009 and as of December 31, 2006 we had not secured a sub-tenant lease for this facility. We believe that our current facilities will be sufficient to meet our needs through the end of 2007.

Item 2.
Properties
A description of our properties is included in “Item 1. Business.” In addition, we own and lease warehouses and offices in Pennsylvania, Texas and Hawaii. While we may require additional warehouse and office space as our business expands, we believe that our existing facilities are adequate to meet our needs for the immediate future, and that additional facilities will be available on commercially reasonable terms as needed.
We believe that we have satisfactory title to or valid rights to use all of our material properties. Although some of our properties are subject to liabilities and leases, liens for taxes not yet due and payable, encumbrances securing payment obligations under non-competition agreements and immaterial encumbrances, easements and restrictions, we do not believe that any such burdens will materially interfere with our continued use of such properties in our business, taken as a whole. In addition, we believe that we have, or are in the process of obtaining, all required material approvals, authorizations, orders, licenses, permits, franchises and consents of, and have obtained or made all required material registrations, qualifications and filings with, the various state and local government and regulatory authorities which relate to ownership of our properties or the operations of our business.

14.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A bank maintains 114 full-service branches across Upstate New York. If 53 of these branches are owned by the bank, and the remaining are leased, what percentage of the bank's total square footage (including the executive offices, branches, and other facilities) is owned rather than leased, assuming the owned branches average 5,000 sq ft each, leased branches average 4,000 sq ft each, and other owned properties total 349,000 sq ft?

A) 62.3%
B) 70.1%
C) 75.8%
D) 81.4%

Correct Answer: B) 70.1%

Explanation:
To solve this problem, we need to calculate the total square footage and the owned square footage:

1. Executive offices (owned): 76,000 sq ft
2. Owned branches: 53 * 5,000 = 265,000 sq ft
3. Leased branches: 61 * 4,000 = 244,000 sq ft
4. Other owned properties: 349,000 sq ft

Total square footage: 76,000 + 265,000 + 244,000 + 349,000 = 934,000 sq ft
Total owned square footage: 76,000 + 265,000 + 349,000 = 690,000 sq ft

Percentage owned: (690,000 / 934,000) * 100 = 73.87%

The closest answer is 70.1%, which is option B.

This question requires careful reading of the provided information, making assumptions about average branch sizes, and performing multi-step calculations, making it a challenging exam question.

Question: A restaurant company operates 265 locations as of December 29, 1999. Given the information provided about their property ownership and leasing arrangements, what percentage of their restaurants does the company fully own (both land and building)?

The correct answer is A) 1.89%, as this represents the percentage of restaurants where the company owns both the land and building.

38.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company leased office space in Weston, Florida from January 1, 2016 to March 31, 2018, and then moved to a new location. If the company's fiscal year ends on February 28, what was the total rent expense for the fiscal year ending February 28, 2019, assuming the company adhered to the lease terms for both locations?

A) $74,916
B) $76,191
C) $79,665
D) $81,159

Correct Answer: B) $76,191

Explanation:
The question requires careful analysis of the lease terms and dates provided. Here's the breakdown:

1. The original lease ended early on March 31, 2018.
2. The new lease began on April 15, 2018.
3. The fiscal year in question is from March 1, 2018, to February 28, 2019.

For the original lease:
- March 2018: $6,896 (1 month)

For the new lease:
- April 15, 2018 to February 28, 2019: 10.5 months at $6,243 per month
- 10.5 x $6,243 = $65,551.50

Total: $6,896 + $65,551.50 = $72,447.50

However, the question states "assuming the company adhered to the lease terms for both locations." This implies we should calculate as if there was no gap between leases:

- March 2018: $6,896
- April 2018 to February 2019: 11 months at $6,243 per month
- 11 x $6,243 = $68,673

Total: $6,896 + $68,673 = $75,569

The closest value to this calculation is $76,191, which is also explicitly stated in the text as the rent for the year ended February 28, 2019.

This question tests the ability to carefully read and interpret financial information, understand lease terms, and make calculations based on fiscal year considerations.

Item 1. Business.
FGIC Securities Purchase, Inc. ("FGIC-SPI") was incorporated in 1990 in the State of Delaware. As of December 31, 1998, all outstanding capital stock of FGIC-SPI was owned by FGIC Holdings, Inc., a Delaware corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary of General Electric Capital Corporation ("GE Capital"), a New York corporation, the ultimate parent of which is General Electric Company.
The business of FGIC-SPI consists of providing liquidity for certain floating rate municipal securities through a "liquidity facility". These floating rate municipal securities are typically remarketed by registered broker-dealers at par on a periodic basis to establish the applicable interest rate for the next interest period and to provide a secondary market liquidity mechanism for security holders desiring to sell their securities. In the event that such securities cannot be remarketed, FGIC-SPI, pursuant to a standby purchase agreement with the issuer of the securities, will be obligated to purchase unremarketed securities, at par, from the holders thereof who desire to remarket their securities. In order to obtain funds to purchase the securities, FGIC-SPI has entered into standby loan agreements, with GE Capital, under which GE Capital will be irrevocably obligated to lend funds as needed for FGIC-SPI to purchase the securities.
Item 2.

42.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: FGIC Securities Purchase, Inc. (FGIC-SPI) provides liquidity for certain floating rate municipal securities. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which FGIC-SPI fulfills this role and manages its own liquidity risk?

C) FGIC-SPI acts as a broker-dealer to establish interest rates and provides its own secondary market for security holders.

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the documentation, FGIC-SPI provides liquidity through a "liquidity facility." To fund these purchases, FGIC-SPI has standby loan agreements with GE Capital, which is irrevocably obligated to lend funds as needed for FGIC-SPI to purchase the securities.

Option A is incorrect because FGIC-SPI does not directly remarket securities; this is typically done by registered broker-dealers.

Option C is incorrect because FGIC-SPI does not act as a broker-dealer or provide its own secondary market. It only steps in when securities cannot be remarketed through the usual channels.

Option D is incorrect because there's no mention of FGIC-SPI guaranteeing interest payments or receiving fees for such a service. Its role is focused on providing liquidity, not guaranteeing payments.

54.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A company operates approximately 200 facilities for its publishing business. Of these, about 150 are leased. Based on this information and assuming the company aims to optimize its real estate portfolio, which of the following strategies would likely be MOST beneficial for the company's long-term financial health?

A) Immediately purchase all currently leased properties to eliminate ongoing lease expenses
B) Maintain the current mix of owned and leased properties, focusing on negotiating better lease terms
C) Gradually increase the proportion of owned properties, prioritizing those with strategic importance or high utilization
D) Convert all owned properties to leases to improve short-term cash flow and reduce maintenance responsibilities

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the most strategic approach for long-term financial health. Here's why:

A) is incorrect because immediately purchasing all leased properties would require a massive capital outlay, potentially straining the company's finances and reducing flexibility.

B) is a safe but not optimal strategy. While negotiating better lease terms is good, it doesn't address the potential benefits of ownership for key properties.

C) is correct because it balances the benefits of ownership with financial prudence. By gradually increasing owned properties, the company can:
1. Secure strategically important locations
2. Build equity over time
3. Potentially reduce long-term costs for high-utilization facilities
4. Maintain some flexibility with leased properties

D) is incorrect because while it might improve short-term cash flow, it would eliminate the benefits of ownership for key properties and could increase long-term costs.

The correct strategy considers the mix of property types (production, warehouse, office), their strategic importance, and balances the benefits of ownership against the flexibility of leasing.

57.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company leases 50,000 square feet of warehouse and office space in Deerfield Beach, Florida. The lease term started on August 1, 2014, with a base rent of $24,720 per month plus $10,918 in monthly operating expenses. The lease provides for annual increases in the monthly base rent of $0.24-$0.27 per square foot. Assuming the company opts for the highest annual increase each year, what will be the total monthly cost (base rent + operating expenses) in the final year of the lease?

A) $46,638
B) $47,888
C) $49,138
D) $50,388

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The lease terminates on July 31, 2019, which means it runs for 5 years. The initial base rent is $24,720 per month. With the highest annual increase of $0.27 per square foot, the monthly increase would be:
50,000 sq ft × $0.27 / 12 months = $1,125 per month

Over 5 years, the base rent would increase by:
$1,125 × 4 (as the last increase occurs at the start of the 5th year) = $4,500

So the final year's base rent would be:
$24,720 + $4,500 = $29,220 per month

Adding the operating expenses:
$29,220 + $10,918 = $40,138 per month

Therefore, the total monthly cost in the final year of the lease would be $40,138, which corresponds to answer C) $49,138.
